scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: In a series of friendly letters Wilder mentions his health and poor eyesight, Joseph's aspirations to be a singer and her marriage to Rudolph Joseph. He also mentions work on "Alcestiad" [A life in the sun], the Berlin Festival of 1954, and a trip to Vienna. Of interest is a letter commenting on Max Perkin's editorial work with Hemingway and Wolfe.

did.unittitle: Thornton Wilder to Miss Stoeger August 5, 1945

scopecontent.p: Wilder writes that his health has improved and that Miss Stoeger should continue to prepare herself to be a great singer of great music.

did.unittitle: Thornton Wilder to Mrs. Rudolph Joseph (Elfy Stoeger Joseph) August 28, 1945

scopecontent.p: Wilder sends congratulations upon Stoeger's marriage to Rudolph Joseph.

did.unittitle: Thornton Wilder to Mrs. Rudolph Joseph October 19, 1945

scopecontent.p: Wilder agrees that the world is full of alarming threats but says that the best each one of us can do is to "work in some discipline, replace hate with love, and despair with creativity." He also states that he is finishing up the "Alcestiad."

did.unittitle: Thornton Wilder to Mrs. Rudolph Joseph April 2, 1954

scopecontent.p: Wilder thanks Joseph for the birthday greeting and mentions the Berlin Festival.

did.unittitle: Thornton Wilder to Mrs. Elfy Joseph January 9, 1975

scopecontent.p: Wilder thanks Joseph for her letter and mentions his deteriorating eyesight.

Wilder writes, "I was eager to give a good account of you to Max Perkins and he wrote me that he had accorded you the rights. Delighted. I've never understood the important part that he's played in Hemingway's and Wolfe's literary life- an author should have no need of a Literary Old Nurse to guide 'em and cut 'em and warn 'em." He also inquires about her music.
Wilder asks that next time Joseph write more about herself, and he mentions his trip to Vienna.
